content:
I'm trying to prove: https://github.com/hrmacbeth/math2001/blob/e660f42b13ddcb6d12b52ba036d6bd071a0cfb9b/Math2001/04_Proofs_with_Structure_II/04_Contradictory_Hypotheses.lean#L84

Got as far as:

example {a b c : ℕ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h_pyth : a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 = c ^ 2) : 3 ≤ a := by
    have hn :=  le_or_succ_le a 2
    obtain h_le | h_succ_le := hn
    -- case a ≤  2
    · have hn1 :=  le_or_succ_le b 1
      obtain h_le1 | h_succ_le1 := hn1
      -- case b ≤ 1
      · have h1 : c ^ 2 < 3 ^ 2 := by
          calc
            c ^ 2
              = a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 := by addarith [h_pyth]
            _ ≤ 2 ^ 2 + 1 ^ 2 := by rel [h_le, h_le1]
            _ < 3 ^ 2 := by numbers
        have h2: c < 3 := by cancel 2 at h1

    -- case 3 ≤ a
    . exact h_succ_le

Here's the approach as described in the book: https://hrmacbeth.github.io/math2001/04_Proofs_with_Structure_II.html#id31

image.png

I don't understand what it means to "analyze all these cases and check they don’t work". How that would look in LEAN code. I thought it might have to do with interval_cases but I don't really know.
Yes, interval_cases seems to work here
@Răzvan Flavius Panda 90% of what you need is in the book. the example before that uses interval_cases

@Kenny Lau Yes, but the previous example shows true things with the interval_cases. Also this is 2 levels of interval_cases on a and b? And I do not understand what I am needing these inequalities for.
@Răzvan Flavius Panda before you write any Lean code, read the provided solution very carefully line by line, and make sure that you understand the justification of each line
and don't skip anything

Kenny Lau said:

Răzvan Flavius Panda before you write any Lean code, read the provided solution very carefully line by line, and make sure that you understand the justification of each line

I always try to read it carefully and understand it, but pieces are missing.
The explanation does not say what is the purpose of showing these 4 inequalities (is that the word?).
Like how am I advancing the proof by having these inequalities?

@Răzvan Flavius Panda yes, inequalities is the word, the point is explained by the sentence before the 4 inequalities:

We can analyze all these cases and check they don’t work:
This implies that c<3. We now have upper bounds a≤2, b≤1, c<3, so a is 1 or 2, b is 1, and c is 1 or 2. We can analyze all these cases and check they don’t work:
did you understand this line?
Yeah, I understand that for those value combinations h_pyth : a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 = c ^ 2 does not hold.
@Răzvan Flavius Panda That's not the full answer.
Do you understand that we are now in the case a<=2 and b<=1?
Do you understand the meaning of the word "case"?
Yes. I think I do.
Do you understand the logic behind "proof by cases"?
if you want to prove that John and Mary are wearing blue hats, you divide this into two cases: Case 1 is John, and Case 2 is Mary
for Case 1, you show that John is wearing a blue hat
for Case 2, you show that Mary is wearing a blue hat
then you have proved "by cases" that John and Mary are wearing blue hats
that's the dual of proof by cases
I think, I get it. Whatever the case, the same goal follows.
proof by cocases?
@Răzvan Flavius Panda then, do you understand that in the case a<=2 and b<=1, she obtained the bound c<3?
What I don't understand is what these 4 inequalities have to do with the actual goal I have to prove. Which seems to be: 3 ≤ a

Kenny Lau said:

Răzvan Flavius Panda then, do you understand that in the case a<=2 and b<=1, she obtained the bound c<3?

Yes.
Do you understand what proof by contradiction means?

That's the first line:

We will derive a contradiction if a≤2.
We prove that if a < 3 then 3 ≤ a and we also prove that if 3 ≤ a then 3 ≤ a
Yes, if I obtain 2 contradicting statements then I can use contradict to prove the goal.
Do you understand that "contradiction" means "false" in Lean?

Kenny Lau said:

Do you understand that "contradiction" means "false" in Lean?

No, it was never explained.
ok
But one of the 2 has to be false since they are contradicting each other.
to produce a contradiction means to produce a proof of "false"
every contradiction is logically equivalent to "false"
Are you saying each of the 4 cases are generating a contradiction?

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

Kenny Lau said:

Do you understand that "contradiction" means "false" in Lean?

No, it was never explained.

"contradiction" itself might not have been explained, but the whole goal of that section was explained at the very beginning:

Sometimes, we encounter a situation with two contradictory hypotheses. At this point, there is no need to prove anything more. Two contradictory hypotheses mean that the situation we had hypothesized can’t actually happen.

It is quite common to encounter this when giving a proof by cases. You might reduce the problem to some list of cases, prove your goal in some of those cases, and prove that the other cases are impossible.

Here is an example of this kind of reasoning. I have written the solution very pedantically, to make the point clearer.
did you understand this paragraph?

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

Are you saying each of the 4 cases are generating a contradiction?

We're generating a contradiction "by cases" here
since we have the bound a<=2, b<=1, and c<3
and our goal is to make a contradiction
then we can do that by cases

Kenny Lau said:

did you understand this paragraph?

I kind of understand what it is saying, but I realize I don't really understand how this constradiction proofs work. I need to look more at the previous examples and get an intuition for how it works. Will get back to you.
Are you familiar with the principle of explosion?
Is that the garbage in garbage out principle, when cause you introduce a false hypothesis you can end up deducing a lot of other false ones out of it?
So first we case on whether a < 3 or 3 ≤ a
in the case that 3 ≤ a, we're done, since that is what we set out to prove.
But I see the goal is still 3 ≤ a even on the a < 3 case branch. And that will obviously never be satisfied.
In the case that a < 3 we show that the hypotheses can never be satisfied, so it doesn't matter if the goal is false since it's unreachable anyways

If you think of the proof as a program (using curry-howard), what we've done is shown that when case splitting, the a < 3 branch is unreachable code so we can do whatever we want with it (including making stuff up, like 3 ≤ a)

Aaron Liu said:

In the case that a < 3 we show that the hypotheses can never be satisfied, so it doesn't matter if the goal is false since it's unreachable anyways

I don't really get what you mean by goal being false. What I see is we know a < 3 and from that 3 ≤ a can not follow.

Aaron Liu said:

If you think of the proof as a program (using curry-howard), what we've done is shown that when case splitting, the a < 3 branch is unreachable code so we can do whatever we want with it (including making stuff up, like 3 ≤ a)

Sorry, I don't follow.
Maths is hard :melting_face:

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

I don't really get what you mean by goal being false. What I see is we know a < 3 and from that 3 ≤ a can not follow.

Clearly it can follow:

example {a : Nat} (h1 : a < 3) (h2 : 3 ≤ a) : 3 ≤ a := by
  apply h2
But h2 is incompatible with h1. How would you even obtain it?

example {a : Nat} (h1 : a < 3) : 3 ≤ a := by
  obtain h2 | h2 := le_or_gt 3 a
  · -- here we have `h2 : 3 ≤ a`
    apply h2
  · sorry
Ah, right, you can just make up stuff. I forgot.
no you're not "making up stuff"
Construct stuff.
it's an if-then-else statement, and it gives you a proof of which case you're in
Ok, I understand.
So, any goal can be proven using contradiction as long as there are 2 contradicting hypotheses?
yes
"if you have contradicting hypotheses, any goal can be proven" is exactly (one way of stating) the principle of explosion
Ok, I will try to make some progress on the proof with "nested" interval_cases I guess.

I did:

example {a b c : ℕ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h_pyth : a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 = c ^ 2) : 3 ≤ a := by
    have hn :=  le_or_succ_le a 2
    obtain h_le | h_succ_le := hn
    -- case a ≤  2
    · have hn1 :=  le_or_succ_le b 1
      obtain h_le1 | h_succ_le1 := hn1
      -- case b ≤ 1
      · have h1 : c ^ 2 < 3 ^ 2 := by
          calc
            c ^ 2
              = a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 := by addarith [h_pyth]
            _ ≤ 2 ^ 2 + 1 ^ 2 := by rel [h_le, h_le1]
            _ < 3 ^ 2 := by numbers
        have h2: c < 3 := by cancel 2 at h1
        interval_cases a
        · interval_cases c
          interval_cases b
          ·
    -- case 3 ≤ a
    . exact h_succ_le

And now have tactic state:

a b c : ℕ
ha : 0 < 1
h_le : 1 ≤ 2
hc : 0 < 1
h1 : 1 ^ 2 < 3 ^ 2
h2 : 1 < 3
hb : 0 < 1
h_le1 : 1 ≤ 1
h_pyth : 1 ^ 2 + 1 ^ 2 = 1 ^ 2
⊢ 3 ≤ 1

So, the goal is false and h_pyth is false.
And I don't know what I am supposed to do with that.
numbers at h_pyth

Aaron Liu said:

numbers at h_pyth

What is this sorcery? It closed the goal.

alternatively, you might like my calc proof better

calc 3
  _ ≤ 1 ^ 2 + (1 ^ 2 + 1 ^ 2) := by numbers
  _ = 1 ^ 2 + 1 ^ 2 := by rw [h_pyth]
  _ = 1 ^ 2 := by rw [h_pyth]
  _ ≤ 1 := by numbers
Those repeated applications of rw [h_pythare funny.
it works :)
Wrong implies wrong.

https://hrmacbeth.github.io/math2001/04_Proofs_with_Structure_II.html#numbers-contradiction

But the pattern is also sufficiently common that there is a shorthand in Lean. If H is a hypothesis whose negation can be proved by numbers, then writing numbers at H will close the goal.
Oh.
Ok, got it. I think...

Why does the next subgoal contain b? **h_pyth** : 1 ^ 2 + b ^ 2 = 2 ^ 2
I thought interval_cases b would replace b everywhere with 1 in goals.
my guess it that the first interval_cases a gave you two subgoals, and then you ran interval_cases b on only one of the subgoals

This is my code:

        interval_cases a
        · interval_cases c
          interval_cases b
          · numbers at h_pyth
          ·
I get b at that last .
Oh.
I think I understand. I need to apply it again.
No, I was wrong, I don't understand how these nested interval_cases work.
Now I am getting a c that is not being replaced.
you should manage your goals better
I do try to indent them with them dots.
whenever a tactic gives you multiple goals, use focusing dots, one for each goal
Yeah, I tried to do that.

here I cleaned it up for you

        interval_cases a
        · interval_cases c
          · interval_cases b
            numbers at h_pyth
          · sorry
        · sorry
Managed to figure it out in the end.
The heat is killing my brain functions, it's 36 Celsius outside.
my preferred way would be interval_cases a <;> interval_cases b <;> interval_cases c <;> numbers at h_pyth but it might not be allowed :melt:
You mean not allowed by the book or LEAN? The <;> has been introduced in the book.

How do I prove this? :melting_face:

image.png
In mathlib, there's a lemma - in the book, I'd hope so as well
Might be called le_succ_iff or similar
That lemma wasn't recognized.
Gemini said: Nat.lt_iff_succ_le {a b : ℕ} : a < b ↔ Nat.succ a ≤ b
That is not recognized either.
Can I just prove it without a lemma?
docs#Nat.succ_le

What's the proper way of applying it?

        have h4 : b < c := by cancel 2 at h3
        have h5 : b + 1 ≤ c := by apply Nat.succ_le h4
Funny, when I ctrl + click on the lemma it takes me to the apply tactic definition instead.
Lol, there was 1 single use of apply Nat.succ_le on the entire internet.

This seems to work:

have h5 : b + 1 ≤ c := by apply Nat.succ_le.mpr h4
Is mpr returning the implication that goes from right to left?

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

Is mpr returning the implication that goes from right to left?

yes

Ehm, I got hypotheses:

h5 : b + 1 ≤ c
h7 : c < b + 1

Like the book asked for, and contradiction won't close the goal.
(Oh yes, succ_le, of course)
you should do have h8 := not_ge_of_lt h7
@Kenny Lau it gives unknown identifier error
what about not_le_of_lt
Worked, and now I can use contradiction.
I don't think I will ever remember these lemma names though.
by apply? and by rw? are your friends.
type the thing you want, and then all the hypotheses you are using (separated by _of_)
in this case you wanted not_le and the hypothesis is lt
if that doesn't work see if it might be an iff
otherwise there are search tools you can use
and of course the #Is there code for X? channel
Thank you for the help guys, the proof is done now.
I'm actually struggling to name things in proofs lately.
There probably are conventions.
I just come up with random names
I have an actual proof where my distance function is named lrd
(it stands for left-right-distance but that is too much to type)
Ah, at least it stands for something you know.
It bothers me that I am solving this proofs with your help and if I'd have to solve it again or solve another proof requiring same lemma's I would probably not recall the lemma names.
Like, I am certain that if I were to try to solve this proof from 0 again I would get stuck again.
And what I would get stuck on would probably be which lemma's to use.
Gemini hallucinated that Nat.succ_le LEAN lemma does not even exist. So aint getting any help from LLMs

for variables, I pick a letter of the alphabet that hasn't been used yet and for hypotheses I try to name them after the variable(s) or other they are "about", so I have a hypothesis about l named hl, and I have a monotonicity hypothesis name hmono, and I have a hypothesis u < 3⁻¹ called hu3
if even more disambiguation is needed then my proof is too long and i need to split it up

And what I would get stuck on would probably be which lemma's to use.

Here's how to approach this problem:

  • Notice the core properties of operations you use. For example, for < it's irreflexivity, transitivity and monotonicity of various functions (for example, addition)
  • Write these properties down
  • Use apply? or rw? to find the lemmas.

For example:

example (n: Nat): ¬(n < n) := by
  apply?

example (m n k: Nat)(h: m < n): m + k < n + k := by
  apply?
For your case, notice that h5 : b + 1 ≤ c and h7 : c < b + 1 give you b + 1 < b + 1 (transitivity) which is solved by irreflexivity.
Did I dream or is there a tool like Haskell hoogle for LEAN? Loogle?
#loogle

By the way, for transitive relations you can use calc:

have := calc
  b + 1 ≤ c := h5
  _ < b + 1 := h7
exact absurd this (by apply?)

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

Gemini hallucinated that Nat.succ_le LEAN lemma does not even exist. So aint getting any help from LLMs

for the purposes of finding lemma, please use leansearch.net or #loogle
There's also https://www.leanexplore.com/.
http://leansearch.net/ is permaloading
But apply? and rw? is the fastest way to find lemmas when it succeeds.
apply? is searching for lemma's to apply?

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

http://leansearch.net/ is permaloading

Try leanexplore.com
Yeah leanexplore works.

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

apply? is searching for lemma's to apply?

Yes, to apply to solve the current goal.
Use have name : proposition to set the right goal.
Type annotations not only make proofs more readable, but also guide proof search.
Can any tool figure out what lemma connects b < c and b + 1 ≤ c ? Tried searching in Loogle but got no result
Thank you for the tips @suhr
exact? might be the tool you're looking for
@loogle ?b < ?c, ?b + 1 ≤ ?c
:search: Nat.add_one_le_of_lt, Nat.lt_of_add_one_le, and 56 more
so many results

example (b c: Nat)(h: b < c): b.succ ≤ c := by
  apply?
@Aaron Liu no Nat.succ_le in results :melting_face:
apply? also does what exact? does when it's possible, so apply? is strongly more useful.

suhr said:

example (b c: Nat)(h: b < c): b.succ ≤ c := by
  apply?

This suggests exact h
this is because of the way < is defined on the natural numbers
Yes. Because these statements are definitionally equal.
You don't even need a lemma for that.

So, I used:

        have h4 : b < c := by cancel 2 at h3
        have h5 : b + 1 ≤ c := by apply Nat.succ_le.mpr h4
Are you saying I could have used exact there?
Oh lol, yes, it works.
No more lemma needed.
You can probably just put := h4 because h4 and h5 are definitionally equal
Term mode scares me. :melting_face:
be not afraid
Does LEAN have an ecosystem of libraries? I mean, for programming, not proofs. And are they easily installable?
First time I've seen := h4 somewhere I was like "WHAT ARE YOU DOING" where's the by
we have Std (comes with Lean) and Batteries (need to include)
Term mode is the best mode.

suhr said:

Term mode is the best mode.

I would have stayed with Agda if I liked term mode :sweat_smile:
I'm really enjoying how interactive proof solving is in LEAN, especially cause of the info view.
Type holes are not fancy enough.

But are people actually considering building a library ecosystem for programming in LEAN also?
Stuff like a web server, a JSON serializer, etc.
We will probably get super-intelligence before we get that in LEAN.
The best thing about Lean is that it allows flexibility of style. You have a space of styles between Agda and Rocq.
Flexibility is good.
And you can also throw some structured proof annotations like in Isabelle/HOL.

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

But are people actually considering building a library ecosystem for programming in LEAN also?
Stuff like a web server, a JSON serializer, etc.

We already have some cool things like verso and lean-regex.
I'm sure people will build more cool things.

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

a JSON serializer

I think this is Lean built-in.
My dream is to have a dependently typed programming language with a proper ecosystem of libraries. So that I can code whatever I want in it.
LEAN seems like a much easier to understand and use Haskell.
Since it doesn't have all the language extensions.

Do you know about SerenityOS and Ladybird? People built whole hobbyist OS and a web browser from scratch.

There's a lot you can build without libraries with enough time and dedication.

suhr said:

Do you know about SerenityOS and Ladybird? People built whole hobbyist OS and a web browser from scratch.

There's a lot you can build without libraries with enough time and dedication.

No, but I know about Touhou which is probably even more impressive.

"There's a lot you can build without libraries with enough time and dedication."

Yes, but it just takes way longer.
And time is a common constraint for software development.

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

My dream is to have a dependently typed programming language with a proper ecosystem of libraries. So that I can code whatever I want in it.

Idris is probably the most industrial strength dependently typed programming language (with a focus on programming, not proving)

@Mario Carneiro Yeah, Idris is definitely the closest we have to a dependently typed programming language with an ecosystem of libraries. But I think it has its issues, like performance and other stuff I can't recall.

The difficulty of exercises in the exercises section lol:

example {x y : ℝ} (n : ℕ) (hx : 0 ≤ x) (hn : 0 < n) (h : y ^ n ≤ x ^ n) :
    y ≤ x := by
  cancel n at h

Mario Carneiro said:

Idris is probably the most industrial strength dependently typed programming language (with a focus on programming, not proving)

I believe Lean is already more mature than Idris.
@suhr as a programming language or what?
As a programming language.
In what way is it more mature?
Mature is a.... interpretable word.

Performance (Idris 1 was extremely slow, and I don't think Idris 2 is too fast either), tooling (Lean has elan, lake and a good language server), libraries (there's nothing similar to lean-regex for Idris).
Idris docs are also poor compared to Lean's docs.

Oh no!

image.png
It has a bunch of unofficial package managers: https://github.com/idris-lang/Idris2/wiki/Third-party-Libraries#package-management
(most of them are already dead)
They reached perfection - why they don't get any more updates :melting_face:
@suhr I am trying to use apply? but it's giving me something like 100 possible solutions

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

suhr I am trying to use apply? but it's giving me something like 100 possible solutions

https://leansearch.net is back up again, I'd recommend using it
Răzvan Flavius Panda has marked this topic as resolved.

Răzvan Flavius Panda said:

suhr I am trying to use apply? but it's giving me something like 100 possible solutions

It didn't find the exact solution so it lists all the lemmas you can apply.
